trans-unit.source: Add authentication to your Windows Phone Silverlight app | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Add authentication to your Windows Phone Silverlight app | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Mobile Services to authenticate users of your Windows Phone Silverlight app through a variety of identity providers, including Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Microsoft account.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Mobile Services to authenticate users of your Windows Phone Silverlight app through a variety of identity providers, including Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Microsoft account.

trans-unit.source: Add authentication to your Mobile Services app
trans-unit.target: Add authentication to your Mobile Services app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to authenticate users in Azure Mobile Services from your Windows Phone app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to authenticate users in Azure Mobile Services from your Windows Phone app.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you add authentication to the quickstart project using an identity provider that is supported by Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you add authentication to the quickstart project using an identity provider that is supported by Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: After being successfully authenticated and authorized by Mobile Services, the user ID value is displayed.
trans-unit.target: After being successfully authenticated and authorized by Mobile Services, the user ID value is displayed.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This topic supports only Windows Phone 8.0 and Windows Phone 8.1 Silverlight apps.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This topic supports only Windows Phone 8.0 and Windows Phone 8.1 Silverlight apps.

trans-unit.source: If you have a Windows Phone Store 8.1 or universal Windows app, please instead follow the [universal Windows app version of this topic](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-users.md).
trans-unit.target: If you have a Windows Phone Store 8.1 or universal Windows app, please instead follow the [universal Windows app version of this topic](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-users.md).

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is based on the Mobile Services quickstart.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is based on the Mobile Services quickstart.

trans-unit.source: You must also first complete the tutorial [Get started with Mobile Services].
trans-unit.target: You must also first complete the tutorial [Get started with Mobile Services].

trans-unit.source: Register your app for authentication and configure Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: Register your app for authentication and configure Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: Restrict permissions to authenticated users
trans-unit.target: Restrict permissions to authenticated users

trans-unit.source: 6.
trans-unit.target: 6.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open your client app project and ensure that in App.xaml.cs, the instance of **MobileServiceClient** is configured to use the cloud URL to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open your client app project and ensure that in App.xaml.cs, the instance of **MobileServiceClient** is configured to use the cloud URL to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: 7.
trans-unit.target: 7.

trans-unit.source: Press the F5 key to run this quickstart-based app; verify that an unhandled exception with a status code of 401 (Unauthorized) is raised after the app starts.
trans-unit.target: Press the F5 key to run this quickstart-based app; verify that an unhandled exception with a status code of 401 (Unauthorized) is raised after the app starts.

trans-unit.source: This happens when the app attempts to access Mobile Services as an unauthenticated user, but the *TodoItem* table now requires authentication.
trans-unit.target: This happens when the app attempts to access Mobile Services as an unauthenticated user, but the *TodoItem* table now requires authentication.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will update the app to authenticate users before requesting resources from the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will update the app to authenticate users before requesting resources from the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Add authentication to the app
trans-unit.target: Add authentication to the app

trans-unit.source: Store the authorization tokens on the client
trans-unit.target: Store the authorization tokens on the client

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: In the next tutorial, [Service-side authorization of Mobile Services users][Authorize users with scripts], you will take the user ID value provided by Mobile Services based on an authenticated user and use it to filter the data returned by Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: In the next tutorial, [Service-side authorization of Mobile Services users][Authorize users with scripts], you will take the user ID value provided by Mobile Services based on an authenticated user and use it to filter the data returned by Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Learn more about how to use Mobile Services with .NET in [Mobile Services .NET How-to Conceptual Reference]
trans-unit.target: Learn more about how to use Mobile Services with .NET in [Mobile Services .NET How-to Conceptual Reference]

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
